title: How to Deal With a Child's Fever Naturally
category_hierarchy: First Aid and Emergency Health Care

methods.name: Keeping Your Child Cool and Comfortable

steps.headline: Encourage your child to drink water and other fluids to stay hydrated.
steps.description: Staying hydrated is important whenever someone has a fever, and fluids may also help to bring the fever down. Encourage your child to drink water or an electrolyte replacement solution, such as Pedialyte, to help keep them hydrated. Try keeping 1 cup (240 mL) of water with a straw in it by their bed, or wherever they are resting. If your child is weak or shaky, you might need to help them drink the water. Other options to keep your child hydrated when they have a fever include fruit juice diluted with water, broth, jello, and popsicles.

steps.headline: Make your child comfortable and encourage them to rest.
steps.description: Being active raises your body temperature, so you might want to encourage your child to take it easy if they’re running a fever. While it’s not necessary to keep them in bed, try to keep them indoors and encourage them to play with something that will keep them seated and quiet, such as dolls or coloring. Try putting on your child's favorite TV show or movie to encourage them to rest. Set up a comfortable spot for them to rest in the living room, such as on the couch with pillows and their favorite blanket.Tip: Keep in mind that your child may not seem uncomfortable at all if they have a mild fever. They might play how they normally do, and if so, that’s fine!

steps.headline: Place a cool washcloth on your child’s forehead.
steps.description: This part of the body has blood vessels closer to the surface, so putting a cool, moist washcloth on your child's forehead might help to lower their temperature. Hold a washcloth under cool running water, and then wring it out. Fold the cloth in half and place it over your child’s forehead. Change the cloth after it no longer feels cool (about once every 10-15 minutes) and repeat as needed. For a severe fever, you could also place cool washcloths on your child’s wrists and groin.

steps.headline: Turn down the thermostat or run a fan if it’s warm in your home.
steps.description: Lowering the temperature in your home may help to lower your child’s temperature. However, be careful not to make it cold in your home as this may lead to shivering and chills, which can increase your child’s temperature. Instead, try to keep it comfortably cool, such as around 68 °F (20 °C). If you run a fan, don’t aim it directly at your child. This may cause them to get chilled. Position the fan so that the air will circulate around them instead.

steps.headline: Dress the child in light clothing and use light bedding.
steps.description: Having heavy clothing items on may increase your child’s body temperature, so it’s best to dress them in light, loose clothing that will allow the air to circulate around them. Get your child into a pair of lightweight pajamas or a t-shirt and shorts. You can also swap their usual heavy comforter for a lightweight one or even just a sheet. If your child complains of feeling cold, give them a lightweight blanket to cover up with.

steps.headline: Fill a bathtub with 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) of tepid water.
steps.description: The water should feel lukewarm, which is about 85 to 90 °F (29 to 32 °C). Don’t use cold water as this is likely to cause your child to shiver and get chilled, which can increase their body temperature even more. If your child is an infant, fill a baby bath with 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) of lukewarm water. Allow your child to play with bath toys like they normally would during bath time if they're feeling up to it.Warning: Never add rubbing alcohol to the bath water! This is an old-fashioned home remedy, but it is ineffective and unsafe. It can cause alcohol poisoning and increase your child’s temperature even more.

steps.headline: Undress your child and place them into the tub in a seated position.
steps.description: Don’t lay your child in the tub. They need to stay seated while you sponge them. Kneel down next to the tub so it will be easier for you to reach your child. Never leave an infant unattended in the bathtub!

steps.headline: Use a sponge or washcloth to spread water over your child’s body.
steps.description: Next, dip the washcloth or sponge into the water and then bring it up to your child’s shoulder. Squeeze the water over your child’s shoulder and let it run down their arm and trunk. Repeat on the opposite shoulder and squeeze water over the legs as well. Do not sponge the water over your child’s face or head.

steps.headline: Continue sponging until your child’s temperature drops.
steps.description: It may take about 30 to 45 minutes to see a 1 to 2 °F (−17 to −17 °C) difference in your child’s temperature. Take your child’s temperature after about 30 minutes to see if it has dropped. Then, take your child out of the tub, dry them off, and get them dressed again. If your child starts to shiver at any point, take them out of the tub and dry them off. If they become chilled, their temperature will rise.

steps.headline: Call your doctor if your child reacts to any medications.
steps.description: Even medicine designed to treat fevers and colds in children can cause reactions in some children. If your child starts to exhibit symptoms of an allergic reaction or if they’re experiencing serious side effects, call your doctor for medical advice. They may advise you to go to the emergency room or they may prescribe a different medication. If your child starts to have trouble breathing, pain or pressure in their chest or abdomen, or their skin turns a bluish or gray color, seek emergency medical attention immediately.

steps.headline: Get medical attention if your child shows serious signs of dehydration.
steps.description: Mild symptoms of dehydration such as being extra thirsty and dry mouth are normal with a fever. But if your child starts to exhibit serious symptoms such as dizziness, decreased urine output or dark urine, and extreme sleepiness, then you need to get them medical treatment. Your child may need IV fluids in order to be rehydrated. If your child is unable to hold down any liquids and exhibits signs of dehydration due to vomiting or diarrhea, call your doctor for medical advice. Other symptoms of severe dehydration include headache, few or no tears, and dry skin and lips.

steps.headline: Seek emergency medical help if your child’s fever gets worse.
steps.description: A very high fever can be extremely dangerous, especially for children. If your child’s fever gets too high, it can lead to serious medical issues and possibly death. Bring your child to an emergency room if their fever gets above 102 °F (39 °C). For infants, contact your doctor if they have any fever at all. It could be a sign of a serious infection.Warning: Developing a fever after being left in a hot car is a sign that your child is suffering from heat stroke. Your child may require medical attention if this happens. Call your child’s doctor right away and let them know what happened and that your child has a fever.

steps.headline: Talk to your doctor if your child’s fever lasts more than 72 hours.
steps.description: A fever should run its course naturally and go away after about 2-3 days. A fever that lasts longer than 3 days could be a sign of a more serious issue. Call your doctor if your child’s fever persists past 3 days. They may want to assess or have you take your child to an emergency room. Your doctor may also prescribe medication to help treat the fever. If you have a child younger than 2 and their fever lasts more than 24 hours, call your doctor.

steps.headline: Contact your doctor if your child has a pre-existing condition.
steps.description: Even a low-grade fever can be harmful to children with certain conditions. If your child has a chronic medical problem such as lupus, cancer, or heart disease and they develop a fever, contact your doctor. They may want to take precautionary measures or monitor your child.

steps.headline: Watch for symptoms that may indicate a problem.
steps.description:
It’s also important to consider any other symptoms that present along with a fever. Pay attention to anything you’ve noticed or that your child has complained about. Call your child’s doctor right away if your child is:
Listless or irritable
Vomiting repeatedly or has diarrhea
Not capable of maintaining eye contact with you
Refusing fluids or can’t keep them down
Peeing less than usual, crying without tears, or less alert than usual
Complaining of an earache, sore throat, pain while urinating, or another specific complaint
Developing a rash

steps.headline: Go to an emergency room if your child has severe symptoms.
steps.description:
If your child has a fever along with other severe symptoms, this may indicate a medical emergency. Call emergency services in your country or take your child to the emergency department of your nearest hospital if your child is:
Crying without stopping
Extremely irritable or fussy
Sluggish and finding it difficult to wake up
Developing a rash that looks like purple spots or bruises
Turning blue around their lips, nails, and tongue
Complaining of a stiff neck, trouble breathing, abdominal pain, or severe headache
Going limp or refuses to move
Leaning forward and drooling
Having seizures
